content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Some twists and good tests make this a great and fun puzzle!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice Puzzle.
Sounds clear & good to me, yes the output could be more complex and of another nature (e.g. shortest path size) but this would also belong to easy mode to me so not much of a difference.

Hi @Suryyy and OK for your Contribution ...
-> BUT according to the instructions, the expected output may not be only a "boolean text" like "good answer A" or "good answer B" ...
-> this rule is especially important for classical puzzles, more important than for "simple" Clashes ! 

=> I suggest you to expect a second value (in a second line, or completing the first one), when there is such path, like the minimal path size ;-) !
-> OR simply expect the minimal path size, if any, and 0 or -1 else ?
Bye ...

✅ Approved the contribution.
Very nice puzzle, I understood it without any issue. I don't see how to improve it besides maybe a bit more diversity in the tests and validators. Approving it!

- You're referencing "H" and "W" in the input, but have "h" and "w" in the stub generator. It would be great to harmonize, either by having "H" and "W" in the stub generator, or "h" and "w" everywhere, or even just have "{{height}}" and "{{width}}" everywhere.
- I've taken forever to understand the "from the first column to the last column of the grid". Could you emphasize that using markup please?
- "The path can be traced both horizontally and vertically, but not diagonally" -> I interpreted this as "either a line or a column must be fully + for you to output 1". It may be more exact to write something like "Every move happens either horizontally or vertically, but not diagonally".
- The interpretation above could be interesting to throw a try and get some positive results before hitting harder puzzles though, and both test 1 and validator 1 should have a full line of +es, to at least get a few percents.

Once these issues are adressed, I'm ok approving the contribution :)

Interesting looking puzzle...

Clear Statement, well formatted, and intriguing.

Looks good.

Input
* Please format "H" and "W" as [[variables]].

* Please format "+" and "#" as {{constants}} and remove the quotation marks.

Output
* Please format "1" and "0" as {{constants}}.

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement (e.g. "write answer").

Thanks.

Thank you for your interest in the puzzle, Code-Parser. Did you try to solve? 

I've rated it as easy because it can be solved using a simple recursion based approach. However, with larger test cases recursion would fail due to recursion depth limits.

I consider making a more intricate puzzle, perhaps one with: larger grid sizes, the length of the shortest path as output, grids with depth (3D), and so on.

Do you see other ways in which this puzzle can be made more interesting? I'd love to know.

Best Regards,
Suryyy

I agree, especially about the tests, which are all more or less equally hard.
Better start with really simple tests: a small one with all +, one with all #, then one with all # except for the first row, then one with all # except for a middle row. That way, the coder quickly has a sense of accomplishment before they require the full algorithm.

Thank you, @Machiavelli_50404!! 

Yes, I agree and just added four different test cases (Direct path, Nowhere to stand, Fully horizontal path and Stalemate) now totaling nine test cases.

Hi @Jp822,

I agree that the output could be something else. However, I consider computing the length of the shortest path to be a problem of medium difficulty. I think I will leave that for episode II of THE OTHER SIDE.

For now, I've changed the goal of the puzzle to outputting the count of '+' characters in the leftmost column from which one can get to the rightmost column.

Thanks for your comment!
Good point on starting with simpler test cases. Thank you for commenting, @Klimpergeist5!
